abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Natural Resources
            Management Project in Niger was  satisfactory, and project
            sustainability is regarded as likely. The overall
            performances of both the World Bank and the Borrower were
            adjudged as satisfactory. A number of factors relating to
            community empowerment in rural areas influenced the
            probability of the project's success: intensive
            sensitization/awareness-raising and flexibility in forming
            organizations; the overall approach to project
            implementation, which augmented social capital accumulation
            and reinforced community ownership as well as the
            introduction of community-based procurement procedures,
            which significantly improved motivation and allowed for new
            capacities and competencies to be developed within the
            communities; community co-financing and "sweat
            labor" the quick and transparent process of approving
            or rejecting community submissions for project development
            funds. The initial introduction of CBPP after the Mid-Term
            Review met with some resistance and procrastination on the
            part of some government officials and community leaders.
            Although these obstacles were overcome through vigorous
            intervention by the Ministerial authorities, they should not
            be underestimated. Entrenched constituencies may jeopardize
            such initiatives and full Government support is an absolute
            requisite for such a project to succeed. Other lessons
            learned regarded the flexible approach to project
            eligibility criteria that was well matched to the diversity
            of community demands. Lastly, the project demonstrated that:
            1) community ownership of NRM development plans and projects
            depends on building a sound knowledge among community
            members of land and resources through simple diagnostic
            analyses; 2) a combination of capacity building and the
            implementation of a wide range of development activities is
            important to ensure the sustainability of NRM activities; 3)
            the distribution of donkey carts as positive incentives to
            youth workers demonstrated the need to directly and
            specificly target women and youth in micro-development
            activities in order to enhance probability of success and
            sustainability; and 4) decentralized NRM activities need to
            be complemented by policy reforms (in particular on land
            tenure) and institutional development components.
